events.name: Berlin GTUG - September meetup
events.description:
The next meeting of the Berlin GTUG will take place on September 12th, starting at 18:30h, in the cafeteria of  Club-Office, a very nice co-working and office space, located Bundesallee 171, 10715 Berlin.

Our main topics for this event will be Google Closure and the Play framework on Google App Engine.

Filip M. Noetzel, a rockstar  freelancer  from Berlin will walk us through Google Closure.  Google Closure Tools is a set of building blocks open sourced by Google in November 2009 used to build products like Gmail, Maps, Docs, Sites, Books, Reader, Calendar, etc. — It consists of Closure Compiler (a JS-to-JS compiler aimed to make your JavaScript smaller, faster and more robust), Closure Library (a rather comprehensive JavaScript library designed for building large applications), Closure Templates (a Client-and-Server templating solution) and a few other tools built around this ecosystem. The talk will provide an overview on these tools, a little background on why things are designed the way they are, differences to other solutions and why you might want to choose Closure for your next web project.

Our second topic will be presented by Raphael Andre Bauer, a regular attendee and presenter at our GTUG, and an awesome local entrepreneur . He will enlight us on using the  Play Framework with Google App Engine and  GWT.

In addition to these 2 columns, we will have our usual Google Tech Roundup, an update on the Google Developer Day in Berlin, and a fun raffle of awesome swags.

 

See you at Club-Office!
events.how_to_find_us: 9th floor in the Kantine

events.name: Berlin GTUG meets on 13th. of February, 7pm @ IS24 Scoutlounge
events.description:
Berlin GTUG meeting topics: Zukunftsinstitut & Cross Platform Development 

After several great GTUG events last year, we want to start 2012 with another highly interesting meeting.

Topics will be: 

the Berlin "Zukunftsinsitut" / "Institut für Internet und Gesellschaft" that was newly founded by Google. Ahmet Emre Açar from internetundgesellschaft.de will inform us about the institute and we will have a chance for disussion, too. IS24, KaufDa, Komoot (alphabetical order) all have a multi-platform mobile strategy and will give presentations on how they manage the cross-platform development process.  Stay tuned for more detailed information on the talks.

events.name: Berlin GTUG Meeting on 26th of March, 7pm.
events.description:
Lets get together late March to celebrate the early spring arrival in Berlin and reconnect on Google technology.

Sorry for the late notice, but we decided it would be better to have a small event next week rather than wait for our late April meeting to see each other again. Therefore we are looking forward to welcoming you in the Less Rain basement, where Jerome will present How to super-charge your startup with Google App Engine, and our usual GTUG updates. Afterwards lets have a drink and chat.
The Meeting will take place on Monday, 26th of March, at 7pm. We'll meet at Less Rain, Linienstrasse 154a, 10115 Berlin.
About our main presentation: How to super-charge your startup with Google App Engine
Jerome, CTO at SnapEngage, will briefly present Google AppEngine, and will focus on why the PaaS from Google should be a hosting platform considered by any early stage Internet startup. The presentation will then focus on good practices to get started with Google AppEngine, and some ways to avoid common issues.

events.name: Introduction to the Dart language, organized by Berlin JS, JUG BB & Berlin GTUG
events.description:
Introduction to the Dart language on 24th of May, co-organized by Berlin JS, JUG BB and Berlin GTUG (first part of the event)

Great news! We´ll have two top Dart language specialists from the Google office in Aarhus in Denmark, the birthplace of Dart, visiting us for a joint event of Berlin JS, JUG BB and Berlin GTUG. Florian Loitsch, one of the engineers in the core Dart team, and Anders Sandholm, product manager at Google, will provide us with in depth information about the Dart language for structured web apps.

The two fold event on Thursday, 24th of May, will take place at co-working space AHOY!Berlin in Charlottenburg near Stuttgarter Platz.

The first part of the event offers some hands-on Dart experience (from setting up the SDK, IDE, to some “hello world!” accomplishment) and will take place from 4pm to 6pm. Please register for the first part of the event. All participants are expected and required to bring their own laptops and power cords. AHOY!Berlin will provide WiFi and 'some' power outlets.

The second part (still seats left) will be a presentation about Dart with Q&A (7pm to 9pm) followed by a get together in the Ahoy Lounge where we can continue with a laid-back general discussion about Dart. Please register at its own meetup page for the second part of the event.

Google is sponsoring this event, including coffee during the hands-on session and cold drinks to chill out after the presentation.

If you want to prepare yourself for the event have a look at the central source: http://www.dartlang.org/,
Dart on G+: https://plus.google.com/109866369054280216564 and
DartWatch on G+: https://plus.google.com/104468597016383470903

events.name: First DevFest Berlin preparation meeting
events.description:
Many of you already know that there won't be a Google Developer Day in Berlin, Germany, DACH, Europe, ... this year. But there will be Google Developer Group organized DevFests in many place all over the world - Berlin will have a GDG DevFest, too.

Google will support GDGs preparing DevFests in many ways and GDG Berlin + GDG Berlin Android are looking forward to have a great DevFest (most probably) in late September (22nd/ 23rd) @ c-base (+additional rooms)

If you're interested in helping to prepare and run the DevFest in Berlin it would be great if you join the first DevFest Berlin preparation meeting on 9th of August, 8pm, at c-base.

The preparations for the GDG DevFest in Berlin are in an early stage and you'll have the chance to develop the DevFest, to meet & work withother GDG members and to be part of a great event. There will be many ways to help, depending on how you shape the event.

Looking forward to meet you on 9th of August, 8pm, at c-base.

events.name: DevFest Berlin & V Hack Android Berlin
events.description:
Berlin calling devs to fest!

After a great Developer Weekend around the Google Developer Day 2011, this year the DACH* Google Developer Groups take full charge and present the GDG DevFest Berlin. On 13th and 14th of October 2012 once again developers interested in Google technologies will gather at hackerspace c-base for a full weekend of exchange and hacking.

The weekend schedule is available at https://docs.google.com/open?id=0Bx8HIzoRcpj9NE5EUEpNZ3Nla2s .

Being part of the global GDG DevFest event series the first day of GDG DevFest Berlin will cover the topics mobile, cloud and the web with talks held by local experts and Google speakers. The second day continues with even more talks, workshops and a small BarCamp. Additionally you’ll have a chance to show your coding skills in two Hackathons. V Hack Android calls mobile developers to action: create an app to celebrate Androids 5th birthday in November and among other prices win participation in the global VHA Hackathon in London. Cloud and web developers however get the chance to show their keyboard skills in the Google Places API Developer Challenge Hackathon. Whatever kind of developer you are: fame and prices ahead!

Register via amiando and Circle GDG Devfest Berlin on Google+ to stay up to date. Find more information about V Hack Android at the VHA site and add VHA Berlin to your circles to stay informed.

If GDG Devfest Berlin somehow doesn’t fit for you or if you want even more DevFest experience, have a look at DevFest Zurich, DevFest Vienna, DevFest Karlsruhe or the global GDG DevFest site for more DevFests showing up worldwide.

Registration: http://de.amiando.com/devfest-berlin2012.html

Schedule: https://docs.google.com/open?id=0Bx8HIzoRcpj9NE5EUEpNZ3Nla2s

Join the G+ Event: http://goo.gl/uaJqh

DevFest Berlin page: http://berlin.devfest.info
DevFest Berlin g+ page: http://gplus.to/DevFestBerlin
V Hack Android page: http://www.devfest.info/vhackandroid
V Hack Android g+: http://gplus.to/VHackAndroidBerlin
Google Developers Event: http://goo.gl/epRWa

events.name: The new Android Build System / Gradle
events.description:
The Java User Group Berlin Brandenburg, Google Developer Group Android Berlin and Google Developer Group Berlin are happy to announce a coorganized event.

Hans Dockter will inform us about "The new Android Build System" ~ Gradle.

The event will take place on 21st of November, 7pm, at Immobilienscout24, Andreasstrasse 10, 10243 Berlin.

Please register for the event at https://www.xing.com/events/android-build-system-gradle-1158931 as we need to know the number of attendees to be able to adjust the room/number of possible attendees.

We will talk about the upcoming Gradle based Build System for the Android SDK that uses proper dependency management and allows for bundle distributions of Libraries. Hans Dockter will present and demo what already has been developed and discuss the roadmap and how the new build system will be rolled out. One goal of the BOF is to provide plenty of room to discuss with the audience their build requirements for Android development.

Hans Dockter is the founder and project lead of the Gradle build system and the CEO of Gradleware, a company that provides training, support and consulting for Gradle and all forms of enterprise software project automation in general.

Hans has 13 years of experience as a software developer, team leader, architect, trainer, and technical mentor. Hans is a thought leader in the field of project automation and has successfully been in charge of numerous large-scale enterprise builds. He is also an advocate of Domain Driven Design, having taught classes and delivered presentations on this topic together with Eric Evans. In the earlier days, Hans was also a committer for the JBoss project and founded the JBoss-IDE.

events.name: Intro to Ingress & What's new in AppEngine?
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

We are setting up a short notice meeting this coming Friday, December 14th, at 18h. The location is not publicly shared for an obvious reason: the Enlightened and Resistance are strong, and are monitoring our group. We have to be extremely careful for your own safety.

Our agenda for this Friday will be a presentation and demo of the Android game Ingress from Niantic Project / Google. Stefan will walk us through what you should know about this augmented reality location based multiplayer mobile game and will show us how things are working.

 

 

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/7/c/6/c/event_187051852.jpegThen, we will get back to work with a “what’s new on AppEngine”. Jerome will brief us on some of the new APIs and services offered to the Google Developers using the cloud services, such as Cloud SQL, Cloud Storage, sockets, etc. with some quick demos.

We will end our meeting with a December tradition: a raffle, including a few Ingres invites this year.

Hope to see you at our undisclosed location on Friday evening.

PS: We will add concrete info about the exact location of the meetup later this week as soon as we established a safe communication channel.

events.name: GDG goes Doc Sprint  & So awesome is Go 1.0
events.description:
Happy New Year everyone!

We hope you had a good start into 2013. We are happy to be back with two interesting topics:

 

Webplatform.org & Doc Sprint on Feb 8+9

For the Doc Sprint on Feb 8+9 we'll be visited by Googler +Scott Rowe, technical writer on the Chrome Team, to introduce us into the WebPlatform.org documentation and why it is important for the web and it's developers to help this platform grow and mature.

He'll also attend the Doc Sprint and you can, too. RSVP here so we can plan accordingly.

 

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/6/5/6/0/event_201265952.jpegGo 1.0

Next up will be +Alexander, co-organizer of the recently renamed +GDG Berlin Golang.

He agreed on giving us a short tour through the magic wonderland called Go, one of the languages developed by Google. He'll also tackle a few important changes which happened throughout the way to version 1.0.

So either if you are completely new to Go or just tried it out a couple of months ago you'll learn some new tricks.

 

Additionally to our talks we'll have our usual agenda points:

Upcoming dates Tech Roundup Member's lightning talks* * If you want to hold a presentation for 5mins we are very happy about that. Please shoot us an e-mail to [masked] or through meetup.

 

We'll meet again at the Google office and seats are limited. Sorry for the short notice but we hope you'll be able to join us anyway!

 

Cheers,

Jerome & Stefan of +GDG Berlin

events.name: Integrate with new Google+ SignIn, use Hangouts API and more Google+ awesomeness
events.description:
We are very lucky to have 4 Googlers from developer relation and Google+ this week in Berlin, and even luckier that they have agreed to present for the GDG community on Thursday evening at the Google office. It is very late notice, but it is going to be awesome.

This session will allow us to learn how to integrate Google+ SignIn, use Hangouts API and simply get more out of Google+.

The event will again take place at the Google Berlin office. We need people to be registered on Meetup.com by noon on Thursday such as badges can be printed and available from the security staff.

 

The 4 Googlers hosting the GDG meetup are:

Ade Oshineye - Google+ Developer Advocate

Gus Class - Google+ Developer Advocate

Chris Cartland - Google+ Developer Programs Engineer

Dawid Ostrowski - Developer Relations Program Manager

See you all on Thursday evening!

events.name: [code lab] Skin the droid in WebGL
events.description:
Join us for a 2-hour code lab on WebGL with THREE.js.

WebGL makes 3D in the browser possible without plugins, THREE.js makes it fun.

In this codelab, you will experiment with the basics of 3D (camera, lighting, geometries, materials) and then with more advanced models and effects (normal mapping, bump mapping, environment map, ...). Only Javascript is needed. No prior 3D rendering knowledge required. Please bring your own laptop and have a text editor installed.

 

About the trainer: +Martin Görner has worked on Mobipocket's ebook technologies which later became the software stack of the Kindle and which he helped develop for a couple more years as CEO of the Amazon-owned Mobipocket subsidiary. He is passionate about science, tehnology, computers, algorithms and everything in between including robots and HTML5. He joined Google Developer Relations in 2011.

 

If you are interested in the talks on WebGL and Ninja web framework you should sign-up for this meetup, too: http://www.meetup.com/gdgberlin/events/115747712/

events.name: Animate HTML5 and Ninja Web Framework on AppEngine
events.description:
We are looking forward to having you at the Google office for our GDG Berlin May meetup.

We will first have +Martin Görner from Google Paris present the current state of animation in HTML5 and WebGl. Then +Raphael Bauer will present a new lightweight Java framework which works nicely on AppEngine.

See you there!

 

Here are some details about both talks:

Animate your HTML5

http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/b/3/1/2/event_228285842.jpegModern mobile operating systems have have made animated user interfaces the standard of computer interaction. They have shown that fluid and well chosen animations create immersive effects and favour intuitive interactions. The trend is now coming to the web. Modern browsers have several dedicated animation technologies built in, running at 60 fps. This talk is a guided tour of the 4 animations technologies for the modern web has top offer (WebGL, CSS3, Canvas, SVG). It should help you decide which one is right for your project.

About the speaker: +Martin Görner has worked on Mobipocket's ebook technologies which later became the software stack of the Kindle and which he helped develop for a couple more years as CEO of the Amazon-owned Mobipocket subsidiary. He is passionate about science, tehnology, computers, algorithms and everything in between including robots and HTML5. He joined Google Developer Relations in 2011.

 

<strong style="color : #000000">Ninja Web Framework vs. App Engine - Win:Win

Ninja is a novel, fast and productive full stack web framework for Java. Ninja is restful, stateless and built on well established industry standards like Maven, Servlets and Guice. This talk will introduce the framework. The talk will also feature a demo that shows how easy it is to write a blog system running on GAE that can scale without limits.

About the speaker: Raphael Bauer is Entrepreneur and Freelancer in Berlin.

 

Usual agenda

As always we'll bring you up to speed what's new with Google and GDGs and will have time for meeting the other Google developers.

events.name: #io13, BigQuery explained, Compute Engine vs. the others, Chrome Packaged Apps
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

we are back from I/O 13 in San Francisco and recovered from all the geeky craziness. Before our summer break starts we invite you to another meetup jam-packed with interesting Google technology.

If you join us at our gracious host ImmobilienScout you can enjoy these talks:

 

I/O 13 recap

http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/2/7/f/8/event_250210232.jpegAs always I/O 13 brought a lot of new announcements, products and features.

If you couldn't find the time to watch all the videos and read all the announcements yet our dear co-lead +Jerome Mouton will give you his very subjective review of the most important news coming out of I/O.

It won't free you of watching a few more of those #io13 videos but it'll bring you closer to the goal of being in the know.

 

BigQuery explained

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/2/9/9/c/event_250210652.jpegWe are very happy to have Googler +Martin Görner, Developer Relations based in Paris, with us again.

He will explain how BigQuery works on the inside in an interactive analysis.

 

 

 

 

Google Compute Engine vs. “well-known competitor”

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/2/7/e/e/event_250210222.jpegSince I/O 13 Google Compute Engine is publicly available.

+Alexander Surma took the time to prepare a comparison to existing IaaS offers and an introduction to the noteworthy features of GCE.

 

 

 

 

Introduction to Chrome Packaged Apps

http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/2/8/1/6/event_250210262.jpegFor a long time now Chrome offered the possibility to enhance your browsing experience with the help of extensions.

With Packaged Apps you can now deliver full Javascript clients to your users with offline features and new APIs.

Our co-lead +Stefan Hoth will be giving you a quick introduction into the new possibilities the new format brings.

 

What else?

As always we'll bring you up to speed what's new with Google and GDGs and will have time for meeting the other Google developers.
events.how_to_find_us: We are in the basement lounge on the left side of the yard.

events.name: DevFest Berlin 2013
events.description:
ATTENTION: RSVPing here doesn't give you a ticket. Please buy a ticket here: https://berlin.ticketbud.com/devfest-berlin-2013

“GDG DevFests are large, community-run events that can offer speaker sessions across multiple product areas, all-day hack-a-thons, code labs, and more.” – And Berlin got its own!

After the big success last year this year, Berlin’s DevFest will be held at ImmobilienScout24, who generously offered us their support. This year's edition will be bigger, offering 3 days and a 3 track program on the conference day touching topics like Android, Cloud platform and web technologies.

Get ready for a full program of developer awesomeness:

On Friday afternoon we are kicking off the DevFest with a Bootcamp on topics like Android, Go or Chrome Apps. Bring your laptop because it'll be hands-on and dirty.

On Saturday morning we are starting the conference day with a light breakfast and after a short introduction you can choose between 3 tracks: Android, Web and Cloud - all day long.

Sunday is the day where you can put all your new knowledge and new friendships to work: It's time for hacking! We are doing a themed hackathon but the theme won't be revealed just yet. Bring your A-Game, built the best app with the technology of your choice and win the respect of the crowd and maybe even prices.

Convinced? Good! Now head over to the ticket site and grab your ticket while we got some left: https://berlin.ticketbud.com/devfest-berlin-2013

See you on Nov 1st!

Jerome & Stefan, your GDG Berlin leads

PS: If you have any questions you can either ask them here in the comments, write to [masked] or ping Jerome or me directly.

events.name: GDG Berlin - December Reboot
events.description:
Dear Google Developers,

A successful DevFest lies behind us and we hope you enjoyed it as much as we did. The 3 day event proved that Berlin has a very active community and there are a lot of people that can share interesting experiences.

More community!

As December is also the right time for reflecting on the past year we can say that we as organizers can and should do better in involving you, the community. Without you there is no group. In that spirit this upcoming meetup has no fixed agenda nor a venue yet because it's about your choice and your contributions.

We set the date and prepared a moderator for you to propose and vote on talks. Everyone is invited to participate. We got this idea from the +GDG Android in Berlin which has been doing this successfully for a few months now.

A few days before the meetup we'll close the voting and select the most wanted talks. The remaining proposals can of course reenter in a later meeting.

Your votes have been counted and we picked the 2 talks. Thanks for your contributions!

Agenda

• 6.30pm: Open Doors

• 7.00pm: Introduction & welcome, looking back on 2013, plans for 2014 (Jerome & Stefan)

• 7.15pm: Lightning talks by members

• 7.20pm: Talk: "Since Go1... it’s been 4 years" by +Alexander Surma

• 7.45pm: Small break

• 8.00pm: Talk: "Polymer: The only true HTML5 framework" by +Stefan Hoth

• 8.30pm: #Techroundup (Stefan)

• 8.45pm: Drinks & Talk

We are looking forward to your suggestions and ideas.

Your GDG organizers,

+Jerome & +Stefan

events.name: GDG Berlin January Drinks
events.description:
A new year demands a new tradition!

We just made that up but it sounds about right. Our goal with the GDG is not only bringing you high quality technical content but also make it easier for each of you to meet people that work with similar tools, languages and products like you. 

That's why we are expanding our regular activities to a bi-monthly "drink-up" in a bar rather than a conference room.  It's a 100% social occasion, in German we'd say "Feierabendbier", among friends and other interesting people. Also we'll have two special guests who want to meet you (again), the community: +Martin Görner should be already well known for his number of talks and events in our group and his new colleague +Dirk Primbs who will be taking care of Germany from now on.

There won't be any talks, no raffles and no other distractions from social interaction, otherwise known as "chatting".

The location this time is not very Google-fancy but rather classic Berlin "pub". We hope you'll like it.

See you there?

- Your GDG Berlin organizers +Jerome Mouton & +Stefan Hoth

events.name: Dart Flight School Berlin - Codelab & Hackathon
events.description:
WELCOME ABOARD - LEARN DART IN A DAY

Dart has reached version 1.0 recently marking it ready for production use. Since there was a lot of interest in this new language by Google we are going to do it right: You are going to learn how to build cool stuff during our code lab and then use your new found skills to build even cooler stuff in the 6 hours-hackathon.

After this you'll be ready to start your next project in Dart. Try it out now here.

AGENDA

09:00 Open Doors, Registration, Welcome

10:00 Start of the Hands on Code Lab: Dart or AngularDart

13:00 Lunch break

14:00 Hackathon starts

20:00 Hackathon ends, demos, award ceremony

21:00 End of the event, let's go to a bar and play some #dart

You can also join our event on Google+ for sharing photos and stay connected: https://plus.google.com/events/c47sj5f3ftel0mpmv5031u0rfjs

REQUIREMENTS FOR PARTICIPATION

In order to make this fly you'll need:

• interest in learning a new language

• basic programming skills (Java and Javascript help the most, others are still useful) - We won't teach you how to program!

• your own computer

• git installed

• the Dart SDK + Editor from dartlang.org + optional the Dart Plugin for JetBrains IDEs (IDEA, Webstorm, PHPStorm). The code lab will refer to the Eclipse based Dart Editor though. Please not that Windows XP is NOT supported by the SDK.

Some code labs might require additional things. We will update the list. Please check it again shortly before the event!

WANTED: speakers & coaches

With a large group of hungry learners we could use every help we can get. Are you interested in lending a hand or leading people through the code lab? Please ping us at [masked]
events.how_to_find_us: The ScoutLounge is the open room in the inner court yard accessible from Andreasstr.

events.name: Google Cloud Platform Live Keynote viewing party
events.description:
On March 25, 2014, Urs Hölzle, Senior Vice President for Technical Infrastructure, and the senior engineering leadership of Google Cloud Platform will be hosting a day-long developer summit in San Francisco to announce new features for Google Cloud Platform, take a deep dive on tips, tricks and technology, and share Google's vision for the future of cloud computing. Bobby Murphy, CTO and co-founder of Snapchat, will make a guest appearance to talk about building one of the world’s most popular applications on Cloud Platform.

The GDG Berlin is organizing a viewing party for the keynote of this event and for one of the first session of the day, at the Google Berlin office.

Google Developer Relation for the DACH region will provide drinks, and the Google Cloud Platform will have pizzas for us.

Join us for this event to watch together live the Google Cloud Platform announcements and to network with the local Google Developer Group Berlin members.

Logistical note: Please make sure your meetup.com profile has both your first and last names in your profile. Google office access requires to have the full name of the attendees (not an alias or a first name) for badge printing. Thank you!

events.name: GDG Berlin Drinks April
events.description:
Meet other developers using Google's products, tools and SDKs over a drink the night before the Google Cloud Platform Developer Roadshow comes to Berlin.

Probably you heard of the Google Cloud Platform Developer Roadshow which will come to Berlin on 11th of April (Did you sign-up yet?). We thought this might be good reason to host a GDG Drinks event right the evening before.

The GDG Drinks should serve as an opportunity to meet new people which share the same interest in tools, languages and products, some of the Googlers that host the Roadshow will be there as well.

At 7.30 pm we meet at Pirates Restaurant, a Place next to Oberbaumbrücke and the Spree. They have good Pizza, Burgers and cold Beer (pay yourself!).

So we look forward to see you!

- Your GDG Organizers +Jerome Mouton, +Stefan Hoth and +Jan-Philipp Heinrich

events.name: Big data using Google BigQuery
events.description:
Hello Berlin Google Developers,

We are very lucky to have Felipe Hoffa (plus.google.com/+FelipeHoffa, twitter.com/felipehoffa) Developer Advocate for Cloud and Big Data from Google, San Francisco, visiting us in Berlin later this month. He will give us a presentation on Google BigQuery including its latest updates. Session will end with Q&A. For a quick introduction to what is BigQuery and its powerful big data capabilities check out this video (featuring Felipe).

Following Felipe's presentation, we will have Aaron Bergemann (google.com/+AaronBergemann_0) Developer at SnapEngage explain how he has leveraged the power of BigQuery to implement the core of the upcoming SnapEngage Live Chat analytical engine, replacing a complex MongoDB infrastructure. Aaron will show some code of the Google AppEngine to Google BigQuery integration, and will demo the visualization layer based on D3.js that renders the graphs on the dashboard.

If you have done a cool project using Google BigQuery, drop us a line as we would love to have you present about it too!

More details on the logistic to come soon. Votum Media will be hosting us for this event. We are looking forward to checking out their nice office setup.

events.name: GDG Drinks July
events.description:
Hello developers!

Meet other developers using Google's products, tools and SDKs over a drink and discuss the latest announcements straight from Google I/O.

Google I/O happened in San Francisco and the extended event in Berlin. That means we have a lot of catching up to do so let's meet and chat over some drinks.

Stefan attended Google I/O and brought some goodies to have a look at: The new Android Wear based G-Watch by LG and a brand new Android TV Dev Kit. We probably won't be in a place where we can demo the TV but it's a nice peace of hardware to look at too.

We're still undecided on the venue to meet at so we're open to suggestions. You should save the date anyway if you're up for some Googly geek chat.

We look forward to see you!

- Your GDG Organizers +Jerome Mouton, +Stefan Hoth and +Jan-Philipp Heinrich

events.name: Building Web Apps Like A Pro Using Google App Engine
events.description:
With falls arriving on us, we will welcome Panayiotis Lipiridis, a fellow Google Developer Export for the Google Cloud Platform from Denmark.

Panayiotis will share with us his tips for building Web Apps Like A Pro Using Google App Engine:
- What is Google App Engine and why would anyone care or use it
- How to build applications on GAE using gae-init as a starting point a framework to very easily start new web application created by Panayiotis
- Why using CoffeeScript instead of pure JavaScript
- Why using Less instead of pure CSS
- Why using Grunt, Bower, pip, etc..

We will also update you on other GDG events comings later this year, and with a quick tech roundup, raffle, etc.

We are very happy to have our friends at Immobilienscout24 hosts us for this event again.

See you there on Wednesday September 17th, we will start at 19h00 sharp.

events.name: Google Cloud Platform Live Viewing Party
events.description:
Google Cloud Platform Live is broadcasting from San Francisco on November 4 and you can join us for our viewing party at the Google Berlin office. We will watch the keynote from 6pm till 7:30pm, and the session "The revolution in cloud computing" from 8pm till 9pm.

The Google Cloud Platform team will discuss how next generation cloud technology from Google allows developers to build better applications faster.

Agenda of our viewing party:

5:30pm Door opens

6pm Keynote:

Hear from Google senior executives, including Joerg Heilig, Urs Hölzle and more, about the revolution underway in Cloud computing. We’ll show new innovations in Cloud Platform, share our vision for the future of Cloud and present some exciting news.

7:30pm social time and drinks

8pm The revolution in cloud computing:

A new wave of technologies is enabling new frontiers of scalability, portability, and developer productivity. Come learn about the revolution in computing, where Virtualization, Managed VMs, Containers and Kubernetes are shaping the next generation of cloud applications.

events.name: DevFest Berlin 2014
events.description:
IMPORTANT: No RSVP here. Buy a ticket to participate. See below for more information.


DEVFEST BERLIN is BACK!

The biggest community conference in Google land is back: For the 3rd time in a row the three Google Developer Groups of Berlin are joining forces to make three days of developer awesomeness happen.

Friday, Nov 21st - half-day of workshops - Android, Go, Polymer

Saturday, Nov 22nd - Conference talks in three parellel tracks: Android, Web, Cloud

Sunday, Nov 23rd - a full day hackathon with a lot of fun and some nice prices

We have some great speakers lined up already and you can check them out here: http://devfest-berlin.de/#/2014/agenda

IMPORTANT: You can't RSVP via Meetup because we want to make sure the seats are taken by people who really want to attend. That's why we are asking for a small fee that is to be paid upon ticket purchase. We promise you'll get your money worth multiple times with workshops, talks, swag, food, prizes and so on. 

You can get your ticket here ( https://devfest-berlin.ticketbud.com/devfest-berlin-2014 ) and learn more about the event on this site:  http://devfest-berlin.de

Let us know if there are any questions!

Hope to see you there!

Your GDG organizers

events.name: GDG Berlin March meetup - Updates on Cloud and what is gRPC?
events.description:
Hello fellows Google Developers,

We are making a slow start in 2015 with our first event on the 2nd day of March.

We will share with you the upcoming events for the beginning of 2015, and we have a small agenda with a presentation on the brand new framework gRPC by Stefan and some updates on the Google Cloud Platform by Jerome.

As our agenda is a bit lighter than usual, we definitely have time for lightning talks about what you are currently doing with Google technology. Send us a quick message if you would like to present.

We are meeting in a new venue for this event. The new co-working that opened late 2014 in Steglitz, Seats2Meet, will be hosting us. Come check it out as you are attending for your GDG Berlin meetup.

We are looking forward to seeing you again. Please note that space is limited, so please update your RSVP if you unfortunately decide to not join us.
events.how_to_find_us: Seats2Meet is the new co-working place on the 2nd floor of the Boulevard Berlin shopping mall in Steglitz.  Easy access with U9 Schloßstr., or S1 Berlin Feuerbachstr. There are several buses stopping in front the shopping mall too.

events.name: Women Techmakers Berlin opening event - celebrating International Women's Day
events.description:
Important: Make sure to use your full name for name badges

International Women’s Day, which is officially on March 8, 2015, is a day to celebrate the achievements of women while calling for greater equality within our communities. As part of the Women Techmakers, powered by Google Developer Groups (GDG), we plan to do this by improving our programs thus increasing women GDG members through increased collaboration and raising awareness through social media. 

During the next months we will cover the different fields of Berlin's startup scene, i.e. backend, frontend and SDK, by a set of intro lecture followed by a beginners workshop, all in the Berlin Google offices. The purpose is to allow those who are less acquainted to learn more, and to those who are already in to expand their knowledge.

Join us for the opening event, with wine and light dinner, to celebrate the start of the program in Berlin. The lecture would cover the eco-system and introduce the structure, and then we will chat, get to know each other and network.

 About the program:

Women Techmakers is Google’s brand and global program for women in technology. Women Techmakers provides visibility, community, and resources for women in technology to drive innovation and participation in the field. Women Techmakers events are designed to promote an environment of inclusivity for women in technology, as well as celebrate women leading the industry. We want to advance, grow, and celebrate women developers, designers, and technology entrepreneurs.

https://www.womentechmakers.com
events.how_to_find_us: Ring the door bell at Google and take the elevator to the 3rd floor

events.name: GDG Berlin April meetup with Noah Falstein, Chief Game Designer at Google
events.description:
Hello GDGers,

We are very fortunate to have Noah Falstein, who is Chief Game Designer at Google, presenting at our GDG event while he is visiting Google for some conferences. Before joining Google, Noah has been a game designer and producer who has been in the video game industry since 1980 working for Lucasfilm Games, DreamWorks Interactive and The 3DO Company. A few of his credits include the awesome LucasArt DOS games such as "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade: The Graphic Adventure" and "Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis".

Noah will share with us anecdotes related to his experiences at Lucasfilm Games in the 80's to his work at Google currently, which are both closely related to the question "How can we use the latest technology to deliver the best game or entertainment experience possible?", and how the answer to that question in the current time is so exciting.

As with our usual GDG Berlin events, we will brief you about what is coming next, what new and exciting things happened in the Google Developer land since the last meetup, etc.

See you there!

welcome to our session of the Berlin Tech Startup Scene (BTS). Throughout our journey, we will split into 4 teams, each doing a different product, that will stay until the end of the sessions. We will think of it, plan it, design it, implement, fix, implement again, update, and implement once more, to see how is it in real life.

To have more sense in this process, please attend the workshop only if you plan to attend the future ones as well. No special requirements for the lectures, there are more spots available.

To get to know our crowd better, and build the content in the best way, please reply to all the questions upon RSVPing.

The first session will be held by Dhyana Scarano and Fei Kong, who will cover the field of Service Design. In the lecture we'll learn about planning the user's journey throughout the product, and this will include elements of UX and UI. In the workshop we will implement this.

We are very fortunate to have Amir Shevat from Google Developer Relations in MTV presenting at our GDG meetup this month. He will talk about irrational product management, covering common mistakes we do building apps. We will make sure we have enough time for Q&As.

Amir manages the Global Programs Group at Google, and has an extensive experience working with startups. events.name: Women Techmakers Berlin - LÖVE workshop pt. 1
events.description:
RSVP WITH FULL NAME ONLY

Hello ladies,

this meetup would be part 1 of the LÖVE for Android game apps workshop.
Ideally you'll attend this if you can also attend pt. 2, but you can also come just for this workshop and get a your mini-version of the game app.

Make sure to fill out this: http://goo.gl/forms/71jI7VMUuo

In this workshop you will:
1. Program simple games in Lua on you laptop.
2. Individualize the games with own code and own choice of visuals and sounds.
3. Port the games to Android smartphones or tablets.

How to prepare:
1. Download the open source LÖVE game engine ( http://love2d.org ) for your platform (Linux, Mac OS X or Linux).
2. If you are on Windows and don't have a text editor besides regular Notepad, download Notepad++ ( https://notepad-plus-plus.org/download/ ).
3. (Optional) If you like to scribble, draw a cat and mouse or any other characters in a hunter-hunted relationship to be used in your game.

We teach girls and women beginning programming skills by developing simple games with them for smartphones as part of the "Einstieg Spiele-Programmierung" workshop, which we translated to be useful for Women Tech Makers.

events.name: GDG Meetup: High Performance Android & What's new in Cloud?
events.description:
Let's meet again and hear some good developer talks.

This time around we'll be co-hosting the event with GDG Berlin Android and we're happy to have two speakers with us: Jens Kuehlers, Cloud Platform Solutions Engineer at Google & also our kind host, and Doug Sillars, Developer Advocate at AT&T and author of High Performance Android Apps is visiting Berlin.

High Performance - What These Apps Did may Shock you
Doug Sillars, AT&T

When it comes to building a mobile application, the performance, speed and battery consumption of the app is often overlooked.  Further, the network connectivity of mobile apps is often a black box that is not well understood. Doug will show some examples of apps with "interesting" network behaviors, and how they were fixed speed up the performance of the applications.

What's new in Cloud?
Jens Kuehlers, Google

It's been a while since we had a general overview of the Google Cloud Platform. Now Google Cloud has grown to 19 products, Jens will be giving an update on what happened in the last two months and what's especially cool when you get started on the Google Cloud Platform.

Additionally you can expect our usual agenda with Tech Roundup, GDG Calendar and maybe even a raffle - and some nice chats with other community members.

NOTE: Google's security requires us to send in a list of attendees with full names on it. Upon RSVP you need to provide your full name either in profile or as an answer to the custom question we pose.

events.name: GDG Meetup: Google Apps Script: The Authentic{ated} Playground
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

Our last GDG Berlin event for 2015 will take place at the Google office on Thursday December 3rd evening.

Martin Hawksey from Edinburgh, UK is visiting us in Berlin. He is an Developer Expert for technologies including Google Drive and Google Apps: https://developers.google.com/experts/people/martin-hawksey

Martin will present to us what is possible with Apps Script: With a pre-authenticated cloud-based ecosystem Google Apps Script makes it possible to integrate into other Google services with a couple of lines of code. This turns Google Drive into a rich playground for a wide range of solutions from custom reporting using Google Sheets as a data interface; quick hacks to get the job done; custom interfaces for Docs, Sheets and Forms; to full blown application deployment to web and mobile. In this talk the main features and affordances of Google Apps Script are highlighted, this will be followed by a deep dive into a demonstration into how Google Apps Script makes it easy to combine Google Analytics with other data sources such as Twitter and do many more playful things.

See you there on Thursday evening.

events.name: GDG Meetup: Microservice Deployment Pipelines with Spinnaker
events.description:
Hello Google Developers and happy New Year!

Our first GDG Berlin event for 2016 will take place at the ImmobilienScout24, in their ScoutLounge, on Wednesday February 3rd evening.

Rick Buskens from Google New York is traveling in Europe for some conferences, and is making a stop at our GDG to meet the developer community and present about Microservice Deployment Pipelines with Spinnaker.

As organizations move to the Cloud, we’re seeing a new generation of DevOps best practices for safely and repeatably deploying microservice-based systems. Historically Netflix has rolled out deployments using an open-source tool called Asgard. Spinnaker – the successor of Asgard and an open-source project as well – is a complete reimplementation of its predecessor and heavily improved. It adopts a key best practice of immutable servers, lets users reason at the level of services and deployment strategies, and works across multiple cloud providers, including Google Cloud Platform. This unbeatable combination of capabilities prepares software so that you can confidently deploy your system to production at any time.

The talk introduces Spinnaker and the challenges it's trying to solve. We will also demonstrate an actual deployment workflow consisting of several Spinnaker pipelines.

See you there on Wednesday!

events.name: Sunday Firebase Brunch
events.description:
Join us for a very special event: Geeky brunch while learning a new technology. How else would you spend a Sunday?

Our Format: Talk+ 2hr Workshop

Firebase is the fastest way to build your app. Come and learn how you can build applications quickly without managing complex infrastructure. You'll find out how Firebase's data storage, user management, and asset hosting features work. In addition you'll get to choose, for which platform we'll live-code a chat application. Web? Or Android?

After the introductory talk by Frank you're free to either build your own app or follow one of these tutorials:

• Android codelab

• Web codelab 


Our Speaker: Frank van Puffelen, Google

Frank is an engineer for Firebase at Google. He helps developers build extraordinary apps that use Firebase as their back-end. If you've ever asked a Firebase question on StackOverflow, you've probably met Frank already.


Our Venue: Scout Casino

Thanks to our host ImmobilienScout24 we can meet once again at the Scout Casino - perfect for a mixed session like this.

See you next Sunday?

Your GDG Organizers!

events.name: Women Techmakers Berlin opening event - celebrating International Women's Day
events.description:
International Women’s Day, which is officially on March 8, 2015, is a day to celebrate the achievements of women while calling for greater equality within our communities. As part of the Women Techmakers, powered by Google Developer Groups (GDG), we plan to do this by improving our programs thus increasing women GDG members through increased collaboration and raising awareness through social media. 

The program for WTM Berlin 2016 is an even greater hands-on experience, more details at the event!

Join us for the opening event, with wine and light dinner, to celebrate the start of the program in Berlin. Facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/238026849871206

AGENDA:

18:00 - 18:30 Snacks and Drinks

18:30 - 19:00 I'm a Woman Tech Maker / Monika Karina Nagay-MarlettiMonika Karina is graduate of WTM 2015 who switched to tech and started a job as a QA Engineer at Castlabs.

19:00 - 19:30 Women TechMakers 2016 / Natalie Pistunovich
Natalie established WTM Berlin in 2015 and is the lead since. She is a Backend Engineer for adjust, an international Berlin based startup doing mobile analytics and an enthusiastic gopher, co-organizing the Berlin Golang meetups.

19:30 - 20:00 Redefining Networking – from Awkward to Awesome / Marina Schmidt 
Marina makes her living by helping busy professionals build a strong, influential network, even if you have little time. She works for Persedu GmbH, the gym for career and finance.

20:00 - 20:30 Break & Mindfulness Session / Ewelina Bubanja
Beat Workplace Stress With Mindfulness Meditation

20:30 - 21:00 - Culture Coded With Care / Debbie Paterson
Debbie is a healthcare UX/business designer on a ‘pre entrepreneurial year’ called My Life Major where she’s exploring preventative healthcare innovation through through technology, culture and design around the world through experiences in government, creative agencies and tech companies

21:00 - 22:00 Networking over drinks

events.name: GCPNext16 Extended Berlin (Day 1 only)
events.description:
GCPNext is Google's yearly Cloud Platform Global User Conference happening in San Fransico on March 23-24, 2016. For all of you who can attend this show we arranged a viewing party, much like a Google I/O extended but focused solely on Google's Cloud Platform. 

Google Berlin kindly offered to host us so it's going to be a fun evening with drinks and snacks.

IMPORTANT NOTES

• Timezones are complicated! That's why the keynote will already start at 5pm Berlin time.

• Security first: As always, Google's security requires us to give a list with full names one day before the event. If you don't use your full name on meetup (which is fine) please fill out the field during RSVP.

• Seats are limited so please free your seat as quickly as you realize that you won't attend.

• We will NOT do a screening of day 2 on March 24th.


AGENDA for March 23th

16:30 - Open doors & Cloud networking

17:00 - GCPNext Keynote  "WHAT’S NEXT FOR CLOUD"

18:45 - Break with drinks & snacks, possibly Cloud networking

19:30 - One of 3 tracks by popular vote: See official agenda

20:15 - More Cloud networking

See you in the clouds!

- Your GDG Berlin

events.name: WTM Android Study Jam meeting #1
events.description:
So you want to participate in Android Study Jam? 
Awesome!

This event is the first one of the session of 4 months, where we'll learn Android development from scratch, and follow the Udacity course Android Development for Beginners.

No previous knowledge is required. However, you do need to be serious and be able to show up for at least 6 of the 8 meetups. If you really want and absolutely have to miss more than two - shoot a message on Slack/Google+.

Some Q&A:

- It's completely free
- It's for complete beginners
- It will take place 1st and 3rd TUESDAY of the month
- April-July: Study Jam
- August-December: TBA
- Last meetup: 06/12/16
- All at immobilienscout24 (near Ostbahnhof)
- Future meetups will be set with time
- Guys are welcome


This is how we'll work during the study jams:

• At home: watch the video 

• In class: recap the material, answer the quiz, exercise and work on your project

• Each participant works on their own project in their own pace 

• Instructors are around to help, 3-5 participants per instructor

For the first meetup you'll be required to do some preparations at home: 

• Follow the GDG Berlin meetups:
  https://www.meetup.com/gdgberlin/events/ 

• Set up a GitHub account:
  https://github.com/ 

• Register at Udacity with the Study Jam link:
  https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

• Create a Google+ account:
  https://plus.google.com/ 

• Join the WTM Study Jam Berlin community (discussion forum) on Google+:
  https://plus.google.com/communities/111601803305788208181/ 

• Join the ADG Berlin Slack (chat): 

  http://adg-berlin.herokuapp.com/
  and join channel #wtm-study-jam
  you are very welcome to join other channels as well

• Watch first video:
  https://www.udacity.com/course/viewer#!/c-ud837/l[masked]/e[masked]/m[masked]/ 

• Have several projects (for yourself - not in groups) in mind

Reach out with any questions, and see you!

--------------------------------------------------------------------

events.name: Google I/O Extended Berlin 2016
events.description:
The three Google Developer Groups of Berlin - GDG Berlin, GDG Berlin Android and GDG Berlin Golang - are inviting you to the Google I/O Extended 2016 at c-base space station. 

Google I/O Extended is all about bringing Google I/O, the most anticipated conference for Google developers, to your doorstep, giving you inspirational talks, hands-on learning, and a chance to hear more about Google's latest developer products live from San Francisco.

Given the experience of the previous I/O Extended events this year we'll only live-stream the keynote and "What's new in Android", not any of the other sessions. But of course you're more than welcome to stay and chat afterwards.

To make sure you won't miss any of the keynote be sure to leave work/home/school early as it will start around 6pm.﻿

events.name: GDG Berlin June 2016 meetup - CSS Container Queries and Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

With the fever of Google IO Extended behind us, we are resuming our regular meetups with 2 presentations from local Berliners at our June event, hosted at Google Berlin.

First, Michael Scharnagl (@justmarkup) will present about CSS Container Queries. The talk will cover use cases, the current state (P(r)olyfills, new CSS properties) and if we will ever see native container queries. 

Next, Jerome Mouton will introduce the Google Cloud Platform key components by replaying the past 6 years at SnapEngage on the Google cloud offering, adding components of the platform one by one to grow from an idea, to a feature and finally to a software as a service serving billions of queries every month. We will cover Google AppEngine, Google CloudStorage, Google BigQuery, Google Compute Engine and also mention some interesting non-Google developer products which complement the Cloud Platform.

Hope to see you there!

Stefan and Jerome

events.name: Progressive Web Apps Viewing Party
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

We hope you had a great summer. Time to get back to our regular meetup and learn new technology together.

Following the Progressive Web Apps Summit that took place in Amsterdam late June, we are having a smaller scale replay in Berlin.

https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/l6B7fZZlPSlCkBf_4tqHzbxF7G0Lz2RCaC0RtiHkfOgXxZHfqu0gvkz8qyXDDkNOkQLqTpUj1d1ZVrldAbFM=w1280

We will first watch together the keynote and a presentation recorded at the PWA Summit in Amsterdam, and will then have some discussion and Q&A each others on the technology. Finally we will do some self-pace codelabs, or if preferred by the attendees, code labs done live on the big screen. Bring your laptop to code along or at your own pace.

Google will provide us with drinks and pizzas. Thank you, Google Developers Relation Germany team!

We are looking forward to welcoming you at the Google Berlin office for this event again.

Contact us if you would like to demo a mobile website leverage PWA tech.

Curious about what PWA is? Check it out here.

events.name: GDG Berlin September 2016 meetup - Web Bluetooth
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

For our regular GDG Berlin meetup, we have Uri Shaked, a Google Developer Expert on Web Technologies from Israel, presenting about Web Bluetooth.

His presentation, "Getting Physical with Web Bluetooth" is a good follow-up to our PWA introduction and code labs from a few weeks ago:

It is time to get out of your web browser boundaries! With a new technology "Web Bluetooth", our web apps are finally able to communicate directly with Physical Devices and control them. Whether it is a heart-rate sensor, a BB-8 robot, or your smart refrigerator - Web Bluetooth got you covered. In this talk, we will learn the basics of the underlying Bluetooth Low Energy technology, then cover the Web Bluetooth APIs, and finally engage in a live demo where we will control a Smart Light Bulb, as well as a cute 3D-printed Robot, directly from a web page.

In addition to this talk, we would love to see what you have been building following our Progressive Web App event last month. If you have something you'd like to demo, please get in touch with us prior to the event.

For this GDG Berlin meetup, The Factory will be hosting us.

We are looking forward to seeing you there!

- Talk: Designing an app: introduction to UX / UI design 

Juliette Bonneviot, designer at FlixMobility GmbH, presents a talk where we'll learn that designing an application isn’t only limited to its visual aspect but extends to the whole experience of using the app. We will look into design guidelines, design tools and various methodologies of user research to see how it can help conceiving the visual interface of an app.

- Live Demo of Adobe XD a simple and powerful tool for designing and prototyping interfaces

Requirement: Download and install the (trial) Adobe XD tool prior to the meetup http://www.adobe.com/products/experience-design.html

(This tool is only available for Mac but if you don’t have a mac, you can pair with another attendee).

- Q&A session and help from the Android coaches.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

So you want to participate in Android Study Jam?  

Awesome!

Come to the meetup to learn Android development, follow the course Android Development for Beginners or follow the Android Nanodegree, both by Udacity, just choose your level.

No previous knowledge is required for the beginners course.

Some Q&A:

- It's completely free
- It's both for beginners and not-so beginners. 
- It will take place 1st and 3rd TUESDAY of the month
- August-December: Study jam
- Last meetup: 06/12/16
- All at immobilienscout24 (near Ostbahnhof)
- Guys are welcome


This is how we'll work during the study jams:

At home

- Work on your Android course at your own pace.

Meetups

- Learn something that is not part of the course.
- Ask for help to the organizers, coaches and other students.

Online

- Slack: #wtm-study-jam: Send Emojis and ask for help.

Interesting links for you: 

• Register at Udacity with the Study Jam link:
  https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

• Course: Android Development for Beginners: https://www.udacity.com/course/android-development-for-beginners--ud837

Reach out with any questions, and see you!

events.name: First Berlin Cloud GDG meetup: microservices, and StackDriver demo
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

Please join us for our first Cloud GDG Meetup where we will have Jose Martín, Development Lead Devops Engineer at Delivery Hero, presenting about how they create services on Google Cloud Platform:

Jose will talk about creating scalable services in the AppEngine ecosystem, focusing on good practices and common pitfalls.

After his talk we will have Cloud SE Nacho Coloma from Google doing a demo about what can be done with the StackDriver portfolio, from Monitoring to Logging to error Reporting. After this second talk there will be a small all-hands session to help us shape these kind of Cloud meetups in the future, in which we will discuss what kind of contents we want to see, and how often should we meet.

Delivery Hero has been kind enough to host us in their new offices in OranienBurger Strasse 70.

We are looking forward to seeing you there!

events.name: WTM Berlin Android Study Jam - The Graduation
events.description:
Agenda 

- Pizzas & Drinks! 

- Talks: 

- Florina Muntenescu: Code, Learn, Share!

- Elena Ognyanova: How to score that tech job

Two interesting talks from two experts that will inspire you to continue learning and reach your dream job.

- Project presentations: 

Time to show your hard work! You'll present your Android project to the audience and receive a certificate of completion for the Android for Beginners Study Jam!

Nicolas Dittberner, from Udacity, will give the awards!

https://www.hub.berlin/en/speaker/nicolas-dittberner

The winners will get a Android Basics Nanodegree voucher!

Please let us know you are going to present your project before the event so we can prepare your certificate!

About our speakers:

Florina passionately works at upday as a Senior Android Developer. She has been writing code for more than 7 years, mostly for Android. Florina keeps a strong focus on clean code and UI/UX. Previous work covered payment solutions at payleven and navigation services at Garmin. Florina is also one of the main contributors to the Android Architectural Blueprints maintained by Google.

Elena has been working in tech recruitment for more than 3 years. She finished her degree in Marketing and Consumer Behaviour in the UK and started her career with an American Software company based in the UK as a talent acquisition expert and later team lead. In 2015, she moved to Berlin and worked with Zalando’s tech teams for 1 year as a tech recruiter. Last summer she went travelling for few months before returning to Berlin and joining Talent.io as a talent advocate, advising the best engineers on landing their dream job. In her free time, Elena is teaching yoga.

events.name: WTM Berlin Android Study Jam
events.description:
Welcome to Android Study Jam for WTM Berlin!

During the Android Study Jam, you will learn to develop your first Android app, including basic XML and Java, creating user interfaces and handling the user input. No previous programming experience is needed to complete this course!

At the meetup sessions, you will have a group of experienced Android developers available to help you. You will also have to follow and do the Udacity Android course at home. It is recommended that you do the lessons at home before you attend to the meetings following the Calendar. About 3 hours/week of work are required to complete the course on time.

If you need to catch up, you can study during the sessions too. For that, bring headphones so you can watch the videos.

The Android Development for Beginners course is split in two courses in Udacity:

Android Basics: User Interface: https://www.udacity.com/course/android-development-for-beginners--ud837
Android Basics: User Input: https://www.udacity.com/course/android-basics-user-input--ud836

Please join the linked courses! They are completely free!

All online communication will go through the Android Developers Group Slack team, please join here: https://adg-berlin.herokuapp.com/ and then Join the #wtm-study-jam channel.

Please try to do the Building Layouts Part 1 before this event.

All genders are welcome! 

We follow the Berlin Code Of Conduct http://berlincodeofconduct.org/

--------------------------------------------

events.description:
Join us on 08/03 to celebrate International Women's Day, as part of the global series of the Women Techmakers global chapters!

This year's theme is Telling Our Story, and in this event we will hear stories of women in the Berlin tech industry, learn about women in STEM and make another step in making our own story.

We love newcomers!
Whether you area a WTM member, or never attended before - this is a great chance to get some inspiration. Our location is the c-base space station, located directly on the Spree. Pro tip: find a c-base member to give you a tour.

Everyone are welcome: this is an inclusive event for all genders, ages, races, nationalities, etc.

★ THE PLAN ★
 
- talks on iOS development, product management and more
- hiring companies for all levels  
- lounge on the Spree
- vinyl cutter machine*
- lightning talks about women in STEM

For the vinyl cutter machine you can buy materials on the spot, and you can use it for making stickers for your laptop/t-shirt/bag/etc. 

You can also bring any t-shirt/bags/etc. to print on, there will be a machine available!

★ THE SCHEDULE ★ 

17:00-18:00 reception

18:00-18:30 Natalie Pistunovich / Women Techmakers Berlin

18:30-19:00 Anna Morgiel / How I Became a Techmaker

20:00-20:30 Mali Baum / Use Your Personal Strength in Your Entrepreneurship

20:30-21:00 Florina Muntenescu / Tech Talks: You Do Have Something To Say! Why and How To Start

21:00-22:30 networking over drinks


★ THE SPEAKERS ★ 

Natalie Pistunovich is a Backend Developer at adjust. Prior to that she was at the Silicon Integration team in Intel, and graduated B.Sc. in Software and Computer Engineering from the Technion. In her free time she is a Golang Berlin meetups co-organizer, Women Techmakers Berlin lead and a sailor.

https://twitter.com/NataliePis

Anna Morgiel is a CS student at the University of Potsdam and a Hunior Software Developer at EMOTISK project. Cat * Bitcoin lover. She graduated German Philosophy from the University of Warsaw and moved to Berlin to enjoy its diversity. When she isn’t playing Bridge at World/European Championships, she focuses on improving in Android Development.

https://twitter.com/aniamorgiel

Mihriban Minaz is a Full Stack Developer at Unumotors, and currently working with Swift/Javascript/Node.js mostly

https://github.com/mihriminaz 

Madeleine Want is a Product Owner at upday for Samsung in Berlin, previously working on products across media, e-commerce and social industries both here and in her native Sydney. She almost never loses sleep, but if she does it's for product management or pizza.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/madeleine-want/

Mali Baum is an International business development specialist. She co-founded Berliner Global Women Organization and Wi (Women’s influencer), a GISEP Ambassador (the German Israeli Start Up Exchange Program), Supersonas Berlin, WIT (Women in Toys - NYC) International chair chapter, member at the public leadership for the Israeli Export & International Cooperation Institute, business mentor for young entrepreneurs and start-ups and she lectures in universities on Entrepreneurship.

Florina Muntenescu passionately works at upday as a Senior Android Developer. She has been writing code for more than 8 years, mostly for Android. Florina keeps a strong focus on clean code and UI/UX. Previous work covered payment solutions at payleven and navigation services at Garmin. Florina is also one of the main contributors to the  Android Architectural Blueprints maintained by Google.

https://twitter.com/FMuntenescu

★ THE HIRING COMPANIES ★

sociomantic, clue, and more

C-base is the crashed spacestation in the center of Berlin. Nerds, SciFi-Fans and digital activists founded the society in 1995. There is an indoors part and an outdoors part, on the Spree. Make sure to bring something warm!

This is a smoke-free event.

events.name: CloudNativeCon kick-off: Kelsey Hightower, Joe Beda & friends
events.description:
!!!!!! Please register for the meetup here Cloud Native Computing Berlin Meetup  !!!!!!

This is a joint meetup of the Cloud Native Computing Berlin and GDG Berlin meetups.

We're happy to welcome four prominent members of the cloud native computing community to our March meetup. Namely, we're happy to present Kelsey Hightower from Google, Joe Beda & Craig McLuckie from Heptio (@heptio), and Thomas Graf from Covalent IO (formerly Cisco).

Our evening's speakers will be in town for CloudNativeCon/KubeCon and are taking the chance to stop by to meet Berlin's local cloud native computing community. We look forward to hearing their insights.

---------------------------------------------

SCHEDULE:

[18:00- 18:30] Arrive and mingle

[18:30 - 19:00] Thomas Graf - “Cilium & BPF - Function Aware Service Fabric for Cloud Native Applications”

[19:05 - 19:35] Joe Beda & Craig McLuckie - “How Clustering Technologies Drive Organizational Efficiency”

[19:45 - 20:30] Kelsey Hightower - "Kubernetes 1.6"

[20:30 - 21:00] Mingle time

---------------------------------------------

TALK DETAILS:

“Cilium & BPF - Function Aware Service Fabric for Cloud Native Applications,” Thomas Graf

Abstract: Modern distributed applications built as highly scalable services require to rethink how security, loadbalancing and networking is being applied. The use of port 80 or port 443 for the majority of communication between services renders network port filtering based security almost entirely useless. Even the short lived nature containers is causing problems as traditional networking tools struggle due the short lifecycle of an IP address. Layer 4 loadbalancers are being replaced by HTTP request aware proxies to provide more meaningful operation such as rewriting URLs, route based on headers, or perform HTTP compression.

This talk takes a deep dive into Cilium, a function aware service fabric that provides a communication mechanism between your services and containers with the ability to gain visibility and control at function level (HTTP requests, REST APIs, gRPC, datastore interactions, ...). Instead of allowing port numbers and IP addresses, your policy will whitelist specific API calls from services identified by labels, limit datastore interactions to whitelisted keys or tables, and specify routing rules based on HTTP headers.

Cilium is built with the powers of BPF, one of the most promising low level technologies in the Linux kernel. It enables Cilium to not only provide efficient communication and control by generating BPF programs specifically tailored to services and containers, it can also leverage BPF to collect metrics from the operating system and associate them with individual function calls being recorded on the network. If you ever wondered how many block IO calls a particular REST API call made to a service has caused, you can find out now.

"How Clustering Technologies Drive Organizational Efficiency," Joe Beda & Craig McLuckie

Abstract: The presentation will center around the emerging world of cloud native operations and how clustering technologies (like Kubernetes) drive organizational efficiency as much as they do infrastructure efficiency. This talk will compare and contrast different operations and organizational maturity models.

"Kubernetes 1.6," Kelsey Hightower

Abstract: In this talk, Kelsey will take a look at Kubernetes 1.6 and explore a few new features such as:

* autoscaling with custom metrics
* custom schedulers
* RBAC
* The Kubernetes CRI

---------------------------------------------

SPEAKER BIOS:

Kelsey Hightower, Developer Advocate at Google (@kelseyhightower) - Kelsey Hightower has worn every hat possible throughout his career in tech, and enjoys leadership roles focused on making things happen and shipping software. Kelsey is a strong open source advocate focused on building simple tools that make people smile. When he is not slinging Go code, you can catch him giving technical workshops covering everything from programming to system administration.

Joe Beda, CTO & co-founder at Heptio (@jbeda) - Joe was a founding engineer of the Kubernetes project at Google. Before that, he founded Google Compute Engine and was the lead engineer for the project. Previously, Joe worked on the Google ads system where he built tools to help advertisers pick the right keywords and bids. He also connected Google services to the public telephone network (PSTN) and defined and launched Google Talk.  

Craig McLuckie, CEO & co-founder at Heptio (@cmcluck) - Craig was the founding product manager for Kubernetes (http://kubernetes.io) at Google, and also partnered with Joe to build Google Compute Engine.  He also worked with Linux Foundation to start the Cloud Native Computing Foundation, where he served as chairman of the board.

Thomas Graf, CTO & co-founder at Covalent IO (@tgraf__) - Thomas Graf has been a Linux kernel developer for 15 years, working on a variety of networking and security subsystems. His current focus is on BPF and how it can be applied to solve challenges of distributed applications. This includes providing secure networking with transparent encryption, application aware security, tracing, visibility, and mitigation of DDoS attacks. Thomas is a contributor to various open source projects including the Linux kernel, Cilium, Open vSwitch, Docker, and Kubernetes.

---------------------------------------------

This meetup is organized by Kinvolk(@kinvolkio) and Loodse(@loodse). It's hosted at the Kinvolk office. Food & drinks will be provided.

events.name: GDG Berlin April meetup: Containing Chaos with Kubernetes
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

For our April meetup, we are excited to have Terry Ryan, a Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform team, coming to Berlin. He has 15 years of experience working with the web - both front end and back. Before working for technology shops like Google and Adobe he worked in roles that combined development with system administration at the Wharton School of Business.

Terry will present how to contain chaos with Kubernetes. Here is a short abstract from his talk: "Okay, you've made the move to containers and can now write Dockerfiles for everything. How do you manage all of those containers?. Have you found that you traded managing individual machines for managing individual containers? Kubernetes, an Open Source container orchestration engine, can be your answer. We'll explore Kubernetes and see how you can use it to run massive collections of containers that fix their own problems and allow you to move your setup wherever you need to be."

For this meeting, Signavio will be hosting us in their Lounge near the Tiergarten at Kurfürstenstr. 110 and will provide drinks and snacks. Thank you Signavio!

After the talk from Terry, Jerome will give you a brief update on some announcements from the Google Cloud Platform Next event in San Francisco.

See you there!

events.name: Cloud GDG Berlin May meetup
events.description:
Hello Google Developers, 

for our meetup in May we have a great mixture of involving user stories, best practices and how-to discussions. Check out the agenda and details for the talks and speakers below. 


Agenda: 

7:00 - 7:15 pm: Socialising - Grab some food and drink

7:15 - 7:45 pm: From scondoo API to scondoo Cloud Endpoints - Sebastian Kurt

7:45 - 8:15pm: Networking with Google Cloud Platform - Jens Kuehlers

8:15 - 9:00pm: Socialising 

From scondoo API to scondoo Cloud Endpoints

Description

For nearly 4 years we built and used our own API. It was running on Google Cloud Platform. Each time we needed a new endpoint we built it, repeating all the steps you do. There were a lot of special cases, outdated authentication, "code we better not touch" and performance was nothing we were proud of. Then we got to know Cloud Endpoints. So we decided to give it a try. Now we want to share some experience.

Bio

Sebastian Kurt, scondoo Co-Founder & CTO/CPO#berlin #triathlon #internet

Studied computer science in Berlin, working in Internet companies for over 10 years. Believes in agile concepts even for small teams. Does sport because there he finds the best ideas.

Networking with Google Cloud Platform

Description

In this session, we discuss cloud networking best practices for securing traditional and cloud-native workloads on Google Cloud Platform. We start with  the fundamental building blocks including subnetworks, routing and distributed firewall. We then talk about how to share subnetworks between different projects, integrate with Google APIs, load balance your services and integrate your Virtual Network with 3rd party appliances.

Bio

Jens Kuehlers, Solutions Architect for Google Cloud Platform

Jens is a Cloud Solutions Architect, building solutions for customers to allow them to scale their virtual networks and infrastructure efficiently. Jens has 9 years of experience working in Google. He started as a Network Engineer working on Google's global production infrastructure and spent 2 years on Infrastructure projects in Emerging Markets at Google Ghana. Before working for Google, Jens worked in technical teams at the United Nations and a German ISP.

events.description:

About the talk

"I will share an overview of Google's AI APIs, which offer easy access to rich, pre-trained models via a single API call with lots of demos, and a brief overview of Cloud ML Engine, which allows training and hosting of custom machine learning models in the Cloud."


About the Speaker

"I'm a Developer Advocate at Google. I build tools, demos, codelabs, and other things to make the Google Cloud Platform easier and more fun to use. I co-authored a book about Google Compute Engine and wrote the product announcement demo. In a previous life, I developed communication systems at Bell Labs and Lucent Technologies. Outside of work, I enjoy indie music, quirky films (especially docs), books, puzzles, and chess. I'm very interested in education, teaching, and applying technology to enhance the learning experience."

08:30 PM - Closing note, networking & more drinks

events.name: GDG Berlin: Designing for Virtual Reality
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

We are very excited to have Macy Kuang visiting us from Toronto. She has been working in the gaming industry for over 9 years and she is the founder of Miaomiao Games. Macy is also the Google Developer Expert for Wearable, IoT and the Intel innovator. In her spare time, she has her own Youtube technical show called "Code To Create" which was being featured at Google Developer conference, Google I/O in 2015. She is as well the co-organizer of the Google Developer Group Toronto and of the AndroidTO (Android Toronto) conference.

Macy will present about designing for Virtual Reality. Virtual Reality is very popular now and designing for this new platform isn't that straight forward. From this talk you will learn the lessons she learnt from my various VR projects.

The second part of our event will be a summary of what happened at the Google Developer Day in Krakow, and what are the latest hot topics from the Google APIs and developer services.

Macy will be available to demo some of her VR games too after the talks.

We are looking forward to seeing you at the Google Berlin office!

Jerome

events.name: GDG Berlin: Cloud Firestore presentation and codelab
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

For our event on Wednesday October 31st, on Halloween day, we are very lucky to have not just one, but three Googlers from the Firebase team coming to Berlin to present at our GDG. Their visit follows the Firebase Summit in Prague.

We will start at 18:30 with a presentation on Cloud Firestore. Following that presentation, a Firestore web codelab in an instructor-led format will take place. You will be able to run the codelab on your laptop, or just watch as it is being done by the Firebase developer. We will then have time for question, and networking.

Here are the Firebase team members we are excited to have at this event:
- Sam Stern writes open source samples and libraries (like FirebaseUI) to make Firebase development easier. He works on a lot of areas, but focuses on backend services (Firestore, RTDB, Functions, etc.). And he’s the team's designated Android nerd.
- Tina Skublics is a software engineer on the Firebase console backend, which focuses on provisioning and managing resources for Firebase projects. Her work includes integrations such as Crashlytics BigQuery export, as well as support for selecting Cloud resource locations.
- Rachel Saunders is a technical writer for Firebase. She writes developer and reference docs for various Firebase services and tools, like Firebase Hosting and the Firebase CLI.

We are looking forward to welcoming you for this second event at the Factory Berlin - Google for Entrepreneurs space.

events.name: DACHFest 2018 (DevFest DACH)
events.description:
For this year's DevFest season, GDG and WTM communities of Germany, Austria, and Switzerland are all working together to organize our largest event yet: DACHFest!

DACHFest is a two-day DevFest conference focused on making a difference. Meet technology experts in emerging fields like AR/VR and Voice UI, discover all the different ways in which technology is transforming lives, find out how to make your apps and websites accessible and friendly towards everyone, learn the secrets of building and nurturing a diverse community — let our speakers surprise and inspire you! And don't forget to make new friends: there will be plenty of opportunities to meet people passionate about your favorite things. ❤️

Join us in Munich on November 10–11 for two days full of talks, workshops, showcases, networking, and fun!

DACHFest is a paid event, but diversity scholarships are available for people who belong to underrepresented groups in tech or cannot afford a ticket.

Website: https://dachfest.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/dachfest

events.name: GDG Berlin: Introduction to Flutter
events.description:
Hello Google Developers,

For our March meetup, we will host Johannes giving us an introduction on Flutter along with a demo.

Flutter is a cutting edge framework from Google for developing mobile applications on iOS & Android. After this talk you will know how Flutter's architecture works in general for creating high performance mobile applications. In the second part of the talk, we will investigate how to build a simple Flutter application with the BloC pattern, which helps you to create mobile applications with a simple and clean architecture.

Johannes Milke is a Flutter Software Engineer from Berlin who recently graduated from FH Lübeck university with a degree in Applied Science of Information Technology and Software Engineering. In his bachelor thesis, he has focused on evaluating Flutter and developing mobile business applications for service providers and their customers.

In addition to our main presentation on Flutter, we will as always present a quick update on what is new on the Google Cloud Platform, and we will give you a quick demo Google Cloud Functions as a way to prototype a service.

We are looking forward to welcoming you at adesso AG. Thanks a lot to them for hosting us, and providing drinks and pizzas!

We are looking forward to seeing you there,

Manjula and Jerome
